column1: Greeneville is a small mountain town in and the county seat of Greene County
column2: Tennessee
column3: United States. The population as of the 2010 census was 15
column4: 062. The town was named in honor of Revolutionary War hero Nathanael Greene. It is the only town with this spelling in the United States
column5: although there are numerous U.S. towns named Greenville. The town was the capital of the short-lived State of Franklin in the 18th-century history of East Tennessee.Greeneville is known as the town where United States President Andrew Johnson began his political career when elected from his trade as a tailor. He and his family lived there most of his adult years. It was an area of strong abolitionist and Unionist views and yeoman farmers
column6: an environment which influenced Johnson's outlook.The Greeneville Historic District was established in 1974.The U.S. Navy Los Angeles-class submarine USS Greeneville was named in honor of the town.Greeneville is part of the Johnson City-Kingsport- Bristol TN-VA Combined Statistical Area – commonly known as the "Tri-Cities" region.

column2: -82.822474). It lies in the foothills of the Appalachian Mountains.  These hills are part of the Appalachian Ridge-and-Valley Province
column3: which is characterized by fertile river valleys flanked by narrow
column4: elongate ridges.  Greeneville is located roughly halfway between Bays Mountain to the northwest and the Bald Mountains— part of the main Appalachian crest— to the southeast. The valley in which Greeneville is situated is part of the watershed of the Nolichucky River
column5: which passes a few miles south of the town.

column1: Several federal and state highways now intersect in Greeneville
column2: as they were built to follow old roads and trails. U.S. Route 321 follows Main Street through the center of the town and connects Greeneville to Newport to the southwest. U.S. Route 11E (Andrew Johnson Highway)
column3: which connects Greeneville with Morristown to the west
column4: intersects U.S. 321 in Greeneville and the merged highway proceeds northeast to Johnson City. Tennessee State Route 107
column5: which also follows Main Street and Andrew Johnson Hwy
column6: Greeneville to Erwin to the east and to the Del Rio area to the south. Tennessee State Route 70 (Lonesome Pine Trail) connects Greeneville with Interstate 81
column7: and Rogersville to the north and Asheville
column8: North Carolina to the south. Tennessee State Route 172 (Baileyton Road) connects Greeneville with Interstate 81 and Baileyton to the north.

column1: Tennessee State Route 93 (Kingsport Highway) connects Greeneville to Interstate 81

column1: Native Americans were hunting and camping in the Nolichucky Valley as early as the Paleo-Indian period (c. 10
column2: 000 B.C.).  A substantial Woodland period (1000 B.C. - 1000 A.D.) village existed at the Nolichucky's confluence with Big Limestone Creek (now part of Davy Crockett Birthplace State Park).  By the time the first Euro-American settlers arrived in the area in the late 18th century
column3: the Cherokee claimed the valley as part of their hunting grounds.  The Great Indian Warpath passed just northwest of modern Greeneville
column4: and the townsite is believed to have once been the juncture of two lesser Native American trails.Permanent European settlement of Greene County began in 1772.  Jacob Brown
column5: a North Carolina merchant
column6: leased a large stretch of land from the Cherokee
column7: located between the upper Lick Creek watershed and the Nolichucky River
column8: in what is now the northeastern corner of the county.  The "Nolichucky Settlement" initially aligned itself with the Watauga Association as part of Washington County
column9: North Carolina.  After voting irregularities in a local election
column11: an early Nolichucky settler named Daniel Kennedy (1750–1802) led a movement to form a separate county

column1: The county was named after Nathanael Greene
column2: reflecting the loyalties of the numerous Revolutionary War veterans who settled in the Nolichucky Valley
column3: especially from Pennsylvania and Virginia.  The first county court sessions were held at the home of Robert Kerr
column4: who lived at "Big Spring" (near the center of modern Greeneville).  Kerr donated 50 acres (0.20 km2) for the establishment of the county seat
column5: most of which was located in the area currently bounded by Irish
column8: and Summer streets.  "Greeneville" was officially recognized as a town in 1786.

column1: === Greeneville becomes capital of the State of Franklin ===

column2: North Carolina attempted to resolve its debts by giving the U.S. Congress its lands west of the Appalachian Mountains
column3: including Greene County
column4: abandoning responsibility for the area to the federal government.  In response
column5: delegates from Greene and neighboring counties convened at Jonesborough and resolved to break away from North Carolina and establish an independent state.  The delegates agreed to meet again later that year to form a constitution
column6: which was rejected when presented to the general delegation in December.  Reverend Samuel Houston (not to be confused with the later governor of Tennessee and Texas) had presented a draft constitution which restricted the election of lawyers and other professionals. Houston's draft met staunch opposition
column7: especially from Reverend Hezekiah Balch (1741–1810) (who was later instrumental in the creation of Tusculum College). John Sevier was elected governor
column8: and other executive offices were filled.

column1: A petition for statehood for what would have become known as the State of Franklin (named in honor of Benjamin Franklin) was drawn at the delegates session in May 1785. The delegates submitted a petition for statehood to Congress
column2: which failed to gain the requisite votes needed for admission to the Union. The first state legislature of Franklin met in December 1785 in a crude log courthouse in Greeneville
column3: which had been named the capital city the previous August. During this session
column4: the delegates finally approved a constitution which was based on
column5: and quite similar to
column6: the North Carolina state constitution.  However
column7: the Franklin movement began to collapse soon thereafter
column8: with North Carolina reasserting its control of the area the following spring.

column2: at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition in Nashville
column3: a log house that had been moved from Greeneville was displayed as the capitol where the State of Franklin's delegates met in the 1780s.  There is
column4: however
column5: nothing to verify that this building was the actual capitol.  In the 1960s

column2: like much of East Tennessee
column3: was home to a strong abolitionist movement in the early 19th century. This movement was likely influenced by the relatively large numbers of Quakers who migrated to the region from Pennsylvania in the 1790s. The Quakers considered slavery to be in violation of Biblical Scripture
column4: and were active in the region's abolitionist movement throughout the antebellum period. One such Quaker was Elihu Embree (1782–1820)
column5: who published the nation's first abolitionlist newspaper

column1: When Embree's untimely death in 1820 effectively ended publication of The Emancipator
column2: several of Embree's supporters turned to Ohio abolitionist Benjamin Lundy
column3: who had started publication of his own antislavery newspaper
column4: The Genius of Universal Emancipation
column5: in 1821. Anticipating that a southern-based abolitionist movement would be more effective
column6: Lundy purchased Embree's printing press and moved to Greeneville in 1822. Lundy remained in Greeneville for two years before moving to Baltimore. He would later prove influential in the career of William Lloyd Garrison
column7: whom he hired as an associate editor in 1829.Greenevillians involved in the abolitionist movement included Hezekiah Balch
column8: who freed his slaves at the Greene County Courthouse in 1807. Samuel Doak
column11: a nephew of John Sevier who served as Greene County Court Clerk
column12: freed his slaves in the 1830s and offered to pay for their passage to Liberia
column13: which had been formed as a colony for freed slaves. Francis McCorkle
column14: the pastor of Greeneville's Presbyterian Church
column15: was a leading member of the Manumission Society of Tennessee.

column2: on the eve of the Civil War
column3: thirty counties of the pro-Union East Tennessee Convention met in Greeneville to discuss strategy after state voters had elected to join the Confederate States of America. The convention sought to create a separate state in East Tennessee that would remain with the United States. The state government in Nashville rejected the convention's request
column4: however
column5: and East Tennessee was occupied by Confederate forces shortly thereafter. Thomas Dickens Arnold
column6: a Greeneville resident and former congressman who attended the convention
column7: advocated the use of violent force to allow East Tennessee to break away from Tennessee
column8: and taunted other members of the convention who advocated a more peaceful set of resolutions.Several conspirators involved in the pro-Union East Tennessee bridge burnings lived near what is now Mosheim
column9: and managed to destroy the railroad bridge over Lick Creek in western Greene County on the night of November 8
column12: were executed in Greeneville on November 30
column13: 1861.A portion of James Longstreet's army wintered in Greeneville following the failed Siege of Knoxville in late 1863.  Confederate general John Hunt Morgan was killed in Greeneville during a raid by Union soldiers led by Alvan Cullem Gillem on September 4

column2: the 17th President of the United States
column3: spent much of his active life in Greeneville. In 1826
column4: Johnson arrived in Greeneville after fleeing an apprenticeship in Raleigh. Johnson chose to remain in Greeneville after learning that the town's tailor was planning to retire. Johnson purchased the tailor shop
column5: which he moved from Main Street to its present location at the corner of Depot and College streets. Johnson married a local girl
column7: in 1827. The two were married by Mordecai Lincoln (1778–1851)
column8: who was Greene County's Justice of the Peace. He was a cousin of Abraham Lincoln
column9: under whom Johnson would serve as vice president.In the late 1820s
column10: a local artisan named Blackstone McDannel often stopped by Johnson's tailor shop to debate issues of the day
column12: which Johnson opposed. Johnson and McDannel decided to debate the issue publicly. The interest sparked by this debate led Johnson
column14: and several others to form a local debate society. The experience and influence Johnson gained in debating local issues helped him get elected to the Greeneville City Council in 1829. He was elected mayor of Greeneville in 1834
column15: although he resigned after just a few months in office to pursue a position in the Tennessee state legislature
column16: which he attained the following year. As Johnson rose through the ranks of political office in state and national government
column17: he used his influence to help Greeneville constituents obtain government positions
column20: who was appointed to the Court of Claims in Washington
column21: D.C.Whilst Andrew Johnson was away from home
column23: both Union and Confederate armies often used his home as a place to stay and rest during their travel. Soldiers left graffiti on the walls of Johnson's home. Confederate soldiers left notes on the walls expressing their displeasure
column25: of Johnson. Evidence of this can still be seen at the Andrew Johnson home. Andrew Johnson had to almost completely renovate his home after he returned home from Washington

column1: The Andrew Johnson National Historic Site
column2: located in Greeneville
column3: was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1963.  Contributing properties include Johnson's tailor shop at the corner of Depot and College streets. The site also maintains Johnson's house on Main Street and the Andrew Johnson National Cemetery (atop Monument Hill to the south). A replica of Johnson's birth home and a life-size statue of Johnson have been placed across the street from the visitor center and tailor shop.

column2: the television manufacturer Magnavox operated its main three facilities in Greeneville. Magnavox at one time was the largest employer of Greeneville
column3: employing over 5
column4: 000 workers. Eight years after the first plant opened
column5: Magnavox workers voted to form a union through the IBEW. Throughout the 1980s and early 1990s
column6: the Greeneville facility saw a fluctuation and drops in employment. In 1997
column7: Magnavox sold its facilities to Knoxville-based company Five Rivers Electronic Innovations. In 2005
column8: Five Rivers closed the former Magnavox plant after declaring bankruptcy.

column1: The rural community of Camp Creek south of Greeneville was severely affected by an EF-3 tornado in 2011 Super Outbreak. Six people were killed immediately and a seventh died later. Horse Creek
column2: southeast of Greeneville
column3: was also hit by an EF-3 tornado during the same outbreak. One person was killed in that community. A total of eight were killed in Greene County.

column1: The Greene County Fair is recognized statewide as one of the best of its size. In 2005
column2: it received the Tennessee Association of Fairs highest award
column3: the “Champion of Champions” fair trophy. In 2001 and 2004
column4: it was named the AAA division Champion Fair in the state of Tennessee. In 1994 and 2000
column5: it was named first runner-up for the Champion Fair in the AAA Division
column7: received the award for Most Outstanding Fair in Tennessee.There has been a fair in some form in Greene County since 1870 when the Farmers and Mechanics Association held its first exposition. The present-day Greene County Fair Association was incorporated in 1949. The Fair exists on the support of countless volunteers
column8: board members and officers since 1949. The fair holds many various events such as the "Fairest of the Fair" event
column9: in which different young ladies are crowned based on voluntary activities and their performance in the pageant.The fair was also an inspiration for The Band Perry's song "Walk Me Down The Middle"
column10: which was featured on their eponymous debut album.

column1: Greeneville is home to the Greeneville Reds
column2: a Minor League Baseball team of the Appalachian League
column3: which began play in 2018. The team plays at Pioneer Park on the campus of Tusculum College.Two other minor league teams have hailed from Greeneville. The Greeneville Burley Cubs played in the Appalachian League from 1921 to 1925 and 1938 to 1942. They won the league championship in 1925 and 1928. From 2004 to 2017
column4: Greeneville was represented in the Appalachian League by the Greeneville Astros. They won the Appalachian League championship in 2004 and 2015.

Greeneville is administered through a Mayor-Alderman-Administrator form of government. The town has a mayor and four alderman
column2: along with the town administrator who is the chief administrative officer and is in charge of supervising all town employees and is required to develop an annual budget and present it to the mayor and aldermen.
